Adaptive Heterogeneous Client Sampling for Federated Learning over Wireless Networks

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) algorithms usually sample a fraction of clients in each round (partial participation) when the number of participants is large and the serverâ€™s communication bandwidth is limited. Recent works on the convergence analysis of FL have focused on unbiased client sampling, e.g., sampling uniformly at random, which suffers from slow wall-clock time for convergence due to high degrees of system heterogeneity (e.g., diverse computation and communication capacities) and statistical heterogeneity (e.g., unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data). This paper aims to design an adaptive client sampling algorithm for FL over wireless networks that tackles both system and statistical heterogeneity to minimize the wall-clock convergence time. We obtain a new tractable convergence bound for FL algorithms with arbitrary client sampling probability. Based on the bound, we analytically establish the relationship between the total learning time and sampling probability with an adaptive bandwidth allocation scheme, which results in a non-convex optimization problem. We design an efficient algorithm for learning the unknown parameters in the convergence bound and develop a low-complexity algorithm to approximately solve the non-convex problem. Our solution reveals the impact of system and statistical heterogeneity parameters on the optimal client sampling design. Moreover, our solution shows that as the number of sampled clients increases, the total convergence time first decreases and then increases because a larger sampling number reduces the number of rounds for convergence but results in a longer expected time per-round due to limited wireless bandwidth. Experimental results from both hardware prototype and simulation demonstrate that our proposed sampling scheme significantly reduces the convergence time compared to several baseline sampling schemes. Notably, for EMNIST dataset, our scheme in hardware prototype spends 717171% less time than the baseline uniform sampling for reaching the same target loss.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, client sampling, system heterogeneity, statistical heterogeneity, wireless networks, convergence analysis, optimization algorithm.

1 Introduction

With the rapid advancement of 5G, Internet of Things (IoT), and social networking applications, there is an exponential increase of data generated at network edge devices, such as smartphones, IoT devices, and sensors [2]. Although these valuable data provide beneficial information for the prediction, classification, and other intelligent applications, in order to analyze and exploit the massive amount of data, standard machine learning technologies need to collect the training data in a central server. However, such centralized data collection and training fashion can be quite challenging in mobile edge networks due to the limited wireless communication bandwidth for data transmission and data privacy concerns [3, 4, 5].

In tackling this challenge, Federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as an attractive distributed machine learning (DML) paradigm, which enables many clients111Depending on the type of clients, FL can be categorized into cross-device FL and cross-silo FL (clients are companies or organizations, etc.) [6]. We study cross-device FL and use â€œdeviceâ€ and â€œclientâ€ interchangeably. to collaboratively train a model under the coordination of a central server while keeping the training data decentralized and private (e.g., [6, 5, 7]). Similar to conventional DML systems, FL let the clients perform most of the computation and a server iteratively aggregate their computed updates. Compared to traditional distributed machine learning techniques, FL has two unique features (e.g., [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]), as shown in Fig.Â 1. First, the training data are distributed in a non-i.i.d. and unbalanced fashion across the clients (known as statistical heterogeneity), which negatively affects the convergence behavior. Second, clients are massively distributed and with diverse communication and computation capabilities (known as system heterogeneity), where stragglers can slow down the physical training time. The system heterogeneity is more challenging to analyze when deploying FL in wireless network, because the communication bandwidth in wireless environment is limited and shared by all connected devices with potential mutual interference [14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20].

Considering limited communication bandwidth and large communication overhead, FL algorithms (e.g., the de facto FedAvg algorithm in [7]) usually perform multiple local iterations on a fraction of randomly sampled clients (known as partial participation) and then aggregates their resulting local model updates via the central server periodically [7, 8, 10, 9]. Recent works have provided theoretical convergence analysis that demonstrates the effectiveness of FL with partial participation in various non-i.i.d. settings [21, 22, 23, 24, 25].

However, these prior works [21, 22, 23, 24, 25] have focused on sampling schemes that are uniformly at random or proportional to the clientsâ€™ data sizes, which often suffer from slow error convergence with respect to wall-clock (physical) time222We use wall-clock time to distinguish from the number of training rounds. due to high degrees of the system and statistical heterogeneity. This is because the total FL time depends on both the number of training rounds for reaching the target training precision and the physical running time in each round [26]. Although uniform sampling guarantees that the aggregated model update in each round is unbiased towards that with full client participation, the aggregated model may have a high variance due to data heterogeneity, thus, requiring more training rounds to converge to a target loss or accuracy precision. Moreover, considering clientsâ€™ heterogeneous computation and communication capacities, uniform sampling also suffers from the staggering effect, as the probability of sampling a straggler (slow computation or communication time) within the sampled subset in each round can be relatively high, thus yielding a long per-round time.

One effective way of speeding up the error convergence with respect to the number of training rounds is to choose clients according to some sampling distribution where â€œimportant" clients have high probabilities [27, 28, 29, 30, 31]. For example, recent works in FL community have adopted importance sampling approaches via exploring clientsâ€™ statistical property [32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37]. However, a limitation of these works is that they did not account for the heterogeneous physical time in each round, especially under straggling circumstances. Another line of works aims to minimize the learning time via optimizing client selection and scheduling based on their heterogeneous system resources when deploying FL in wireless networks [38, 14, 15, 39, 16, 40, 17, 41, 42, 43, 44, 18, 45, 46]. However, their optimization schemes did not consider how client selection schemes influence the convergence behavior (e.g., the number of rounds for convergence) due to data heterogeneity and thus affect the total learning time.

In a nutshell, the fundamental limitation of existing works is the lack of joint consideration on the impact of the inherent system heterogeneity and statistical heterogeneity on client sampling. In other words, clients with valuable data may have poor computation and communication capabilities, whereas those who compute or communicate fast may have low-quality data. This motivates us to study the following key question.

Key Question: How to design an optimal client sampling scheme for wireless FL that tackles both system and statistical heterogeneity to achieve fast convergence with respect to wall-clock time?

The challenge of the above question is threefold: (1) It is difficult to obtain an expected per-round training time for arbitrary client sampling probability due to the straggling effect in wireless networks. (2) It is challenging to derive an analytical FL convergence result for arbitrary client sampling probability. (3) The total convergence time minimization problem can be non-convex and with unknown coefficients, which we can only estimate during the learning process (known as the chicken-and-egg problem).

In light of the above discussion, we state the main results and key contributions of this paper as follows:

  • â€¢

    Optimal Heterogeneous Client Sampling for FL over Wireless Networks: We study how to design the optimal client sampling strategy in wireless networks to minimize FL convergence time. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that aims to optimize the client sampling probability to address both clientsâ€™ system and statistical heterogeneity.

  • â€¢

    Adaptive Bandwidth Allocation for Arbitrary Client Sampling: Considering the wireless bandwidth limitation and interference, we propose an adaptive bandwidth allocation scheme for arbitrary sampled clients to address the straggling effect in each round. For arbitrary client sampling probability, we characterize the expected time per-round and identify the impact of clientsâ€™ heterogeneous computation and communication capacities as well as the limited system bandwidth.

  • â€¢

    Optimization Algorithm with Convergence Guarantee: We provide a generic methodology to conduct FL wall-clock time optimization for arbitrary client sampling probability while ensuring convergence. A step in this method is to make a minor modification to the existing FedAvg algorithm and its convergence bound. This enables us to formulate an offline non-convex optimization problem with respect to the client sampling probability without actually training the model, where the problem captures both system and statistical heterogeneity. We propose a low-cost substitute sampling approach to learn the convergence-related unknown parameters and develop an efficient algorithm to approximately solve the non-convex problem with low computational complexity.

  • â€¢

    Optimal Client Sampling Principle: Our solution characterizes the impact of system heterogeneity (e.g., clientsâ€™ computation and communication time) and statistical heterogeneity (e.g., clientsâ€™ data quantity and quality) on the optimal client sampling probability. Moreover, our solution reveals that as the number of sampled clients increases, the total convergence time first decreases and then increases because a larger sampling number reduces the number of rounds for convergence but results in a longer expected time per-round due to limited wireless bandwidth.

  • â€¢

    Simulation and Prototype Experimentation: We evaluate the performance of our proposed algorithms through both a simulated environment and a hardware prototype. Experimental results from both real and synthetic datasets demonstrate that our proposed sampling scheme can significantly reduce the convergence time compared to several baseline sampling schemes. For example, for hardware prototype with EMNIST dataset, our sampling scheme spends 717171% less time than baseline uniform sampling for reaching the same target loss. We also show that our proposed sampling performs well even when the strong convexity assumption is violated, e.g., for non-convex loss function. We open sourced our experiment code at https://github.com/WENLIXIAO-CS/WirelessFL.

2 Related Work

Active client sampling and selection play a crucial role in addressing the statistical and system heterogeneity challenges in cross-device FL. In the existing literature, the research efforts in speeding up the training process mainly focus on two aspects: importance sampling and resource-aware optimization-based approaches.

The goal of the importance sampling is to reduce the high variance in traditional stochastic optimization algorithms of stochastic gradient descent (SGD), where data samples are drawn uniformly at random during the learning process (e.g., [27, 28, 29, 30, 31]). The intuition of importance sampling is to estimate a random variable by seeing important examples more often, but use them less. Recent works have adopted this idea in FL systems to improve communication efficiency via reducing the variance of the aggregated model update. Specifically, clients with â€œimportant" data would have higher probabilities to be sampled in each round. For example, existing works use clientsâ€™ local gradient information (e.g., [32, 33, 34]) or local losses (e.g., [35, 36, 37]) to measure the importance of clientsâ€™ data. However, these schemes did not consider the speed of error convergence with respect to wall-clock time, especially the straggling effect due to heterogeneous transmission delays.

Another line of works aims to minimize wall-clock time via resource-aware optimization-based approaches in mobile edge networks, such as CPU frequency allocation (e.g., [38]), and communication bandwidth allocation (e.g., [14, 15, 39]), straggler-aware client scheduling (e.g., [16, 40, 17, 41, 42, 43]), parameters control (e.g., [44, 18]), and task offloading (e.g., [45, 46]). While these papers provided some novel insights, their optimization approaches did not show how client sampling could affect the total convergence time and thus are orthogonal to our work.

Unlike all the above-mentioned works, our work focuses on how to design the optimal client sampling strategy that tackles both system and statistical heterogeneity to minimize the wall-clock time with convergence guarantees. In addition, most existing works on FL are based on computer simulations. In contrast, we implement our algorithm in an actual hardware prototype with resource-constrained devices, which allows us to capture real heterogeneous system operation time.

The organization of the rest of the paper is as follows. SectionÂ 3 introduces the system model and problem formulation. SectionÂ 4 presents our new error-convergence bound with arbitrary client sampling. SectionÂ 5 gives the optimal client sampling algorithm and solution insights. SectionÂ 6 provides the simulation and prototype experimental results. We conclude this paper in SectionÂ 7.

3 Preliminaries and System Model

We start by summarizing the basics of FL and its de facto algorithm FedAvg with unbiased client sampling. Then, we introduce the proposed adaptive client sampling in wireless networks with statistical and system heterogeneity based on FedAvg. Finally, we present our formulated optimization problem. We summarize all key notations in this paper in TableÂ I.

Recent works have demonstrated the effectiveness of FedAvg with theoretical convergence guarantees in various settings [23, 21, 22, 24, 25]. However, these works assume that the server samples clients either uniformly at random or proportional to data size, which may slow down the wall-clock time for convergence due to the straggling effect e.g., clientsâ€™ non-i.i.d. data and diverse computational and communication capabilities. Thus, a careful client sampling design should tackle both system and statistical heterogeneity for fast convergence.

3.2 FL Client Sampling over Wireless Networks

We aim to sample clients according to a probability distribution ğ’’={qi,âˆ€iâˆˆğ’©}ğ’’subscriptğ‘ğ‘–for-allğ‘–ğ’©\boldsymbol{q}\!=\!\{q_{i},\forall i\!\in\!\mathcal{N}\}, where 0â‰¤qiâ‰¤10subscriptğ‘ğ‘–10\!\leq\!q_{i}\!\leq\!1 and âˆ‘i=1Nqi=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\!=\!1. Through optimizing ğ’’ğ’’\boldsymbol{q}, we want to address system and statistical heterogeneity so as to minimize the wall-clock time for convergence. We describe the system model as follows.

3.2.1 Client Sampling Model

We consider a standard FL setting where the training data are distributed in an unbalanced and non-i.i.d. fashion among clients. Following recent works [10, 23, 21, 22, 24, 25], We assume that the server creates the sampled client set ğ’¦(r)â€‹(ğ’’)superscriptğ’¦ğ‘Ÿğ’’\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}) by sampling Kğ¾K times, with replacement, from the total Nğ‘N clients for analytically tractable results. In this scenario, a client may appear multiple times in ğ’¦(r)â€‹(ğ’’)superscriptğ’¦ğ‘Ÿğ’’\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}). The aggregation weight for each client iğ‘–i corresponds to the frequency of its appearance in ğ’¦(r)â€‹(ğ’’)superscriptğ’¦ğ‘Ÿğ’’\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}).

3.2.2 System Heterogeneity Model

As illustrated in Fig.Â 1, due to system bandwidth limitation and wireless interference, we assume that the sampled clients are scheduled in a frequency-sharing manner, and each particular clientâ€™s computation time for local model updates is static throughout the learning period as [15, 14, 20]. Nevertheless, each clientâ€™s communication time for model uploading varies across rounds, as the communication time depends on the allocated bandwidth in each round.444We do not consider the serverâ€™s downlink time for model broadcasting and model aggregation, as we mainly focus on the performance bottleneck of the battery-constrained edge devices. For example, the server may allocate different bandwidth for the same client in different rounds due to the randomly changing sampled client set.

3.2.3 Joint Computation and Communication Design

We consider the mainstream synchronized555As suggested [47, 48, 49], we consider mainstream synchronized FL in this paper due to its composability with other techniques (such as secure aggregation protocols and differential privacy). FL framework (e.g., [7, 8, 23, 21, 22, 24, 25]), where the server waits to collect and aggregate all sampled clientsâ€™ model updates before entering the next round. For FL operating in the synchronized fashion, the per-round time is limited by the slowest client (known as straggler). 3.3 Problem Formulation

Our goal is to minimize the expected total learning time ğ”¼â€‹[Ttotâ€‹(ğ’’,R)]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡totğ’’ğ‘…\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(\boldsymbol{q},R)], while ensuring that the expected global loss ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğ°(R)â€‹(ğ’’))]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹superscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ’’\mathbb{E}[F\left(\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] converges to the minimum value Fâˆ—superscriptğ¹F^{*} with an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon precision, with ğ°(R)â€‹(ğ’’)superscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ’’\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q}) being the aggregated global model after Rğ‘…R rounds with client sampling probability ğ’’ğ’’\boldsymbol{q}. Hence, it is difficult to analyze how clientsâ€™ heterogeneous computation time (i.e., Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i}), communication time (i.e., tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}), and the total bandwidth affect the optimal client sampling. Even for the simplest case, e.g., K=1ğ¾1K=1, Problem P1 can be non-convex as we will show later.

In SectionÂ 4 and SectionÂ 5, we address these two challenges, respectively, and propose approximate algorithms to find an approximate solution to Problem P1 efficiently.

4 Convergence Bound for Arbitrary Client Sampling

In this section, we address the first challenge by deriving a new tractable error-convergence bound for arbitrary client sampling probability.

4.1 Machine Learning Model Assumptions

To ensure a tractable convergence analysis, we first state several assumptions on the local objective functions Fiâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ°{F_{i}}\left(\mathbf{w}\right).

Assumption 1.

L-smooth: For each client iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\mathcal{N}, Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i} is Lğ¿L-smooth for all ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v} and ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}, â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ¯)âˆ’âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ°)â€–â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–ğ¯âˆ’ğ°â€–normâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ¯âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ°ğ¿normğ¯ğ°\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{v})-\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|.

Assumption 2.

Strongly-convex: For each client iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\mathcal{N}, Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i} is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex for all ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v} and ğ°,Fi(ğ¯)â‰¥Fi(ğ°)+(ğ¯âˆ’\mathbf{w},F_{i}(\mathbf{v})\geq F_{i}(\mathbf{w})+(\mathbf{v}- ğ°)Tâˆ‡Fi(ğ°)+Î¼2âˆ¥ğ¯âˆ’ğ°âˆ¥22\mathbf{w})^{T}\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2}.

Assumption 3.

Bounded local variance: For each client iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\mathcal{N} after the Ï„ğœ\tauth iteration, the variance of its stochastic gradient is bounded: ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ°i(Ï„),Î¾i(Ï„))âˆ’âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ°i(Ï„))â€–2â‰¤Ïƒi2ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘–ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğœâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘–ğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(\tau)},\xi_{i}^{(\tau)}\right)\!-\!\nabla F_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(\tau)}\right)\right\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{i}^{2}.

Assumptions 1â€“3 are common in many existing studies of convex FL problems, such as â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-norm regularized linear regression, logistic regression (e.g., [23, 11, 32, 50, 25, 35]). Nevertheless, the experimental results to be presented in Section VI show that our results also works well for non-convex function such as neural network.

Remark: The interpretation of our sampling and aggregation is similar to that of importance sampling. We summarize how the server performs client sampling and model aggregation in AlgorithmÂ 1, where the main differences compared to the de facto FedAvg in [7] are the Sampling (StepÂ 1) and Aggregation (StepÂ 1) procedures. Notably, AlgorithmÂ 1 recovers variants of the FedAvg algorithm as special cases as in reference [23]. For instance, when qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–q_{i} is set to 1N1ğ‘\frac{1}{N}, it means uniform sampling with replacement. If qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–q_{i} is set to pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}, it refers to weighted sampling with replacement.

We summarize the key insights of TheoremÂ 1 as follows:

  • â€¢

    The convergence bound in (11) establishes the relationship between client sampling probability ğ’’ğ’’\boldsymbol{q} and the number of rounds Rğ‘…R for the expected loss ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğ°(R)â€‹(ğ’’))]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹superscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ’’\mathbb{E}[F\left(\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] reaching the target Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon precision. Notably, the derived bound generalizes the convergence results in [23], where clients are uniformly sampled (qi=1/Nsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘q_{i}={1}/{N}) or weighted sampled (qi=pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–q_{i}=p_{i}).

  • â€¢

    The convergence bound in (11) indicates that in order to obtain an unbiased global model, all clients need to be sampled with non-zero probability for model convergence, i.e., qi>0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0q_{i}>0, for all client iğ‘–i. This is because when qiâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0q_{i}\rightarrow 0, it will take infinite number of rounds for convergence.

  • â€¢

    The convergence bound in (11) characterizes the impact of clientsâ€™ heterogeneous data, e.g., piâ€‹Gisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğºğ‘–p_{i}G_{i} on the convergence rate.

5 Adaptive Client Sampling Algorithm

In this section, we first obtain the analytical lower and upper bound of the expected total learning time ğ”¼â€‹[Ttot]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡tot\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}] with sampling probability ğ’’ğ’’\boldsymbol{q} and training round Rğ‘…R. Then, we formulate an analytical approximate problem of the original Problem P1 based on the convergence upper bound in TheoremÂ 1. Finally, we develop an efficient algorithm to solve the new problem with insightful sampling principles.

Here, we note that any optimization for minimizing the FL training time has the challenge that, before the model has been fully trained, it is generally impossible to know exactly how different FL configurations affect the FL performance. Therefore, to optimize the FL performance, we need to have a lightweight surrogate that can (approximately) predict what will happen if we choose a specific configuration. We use the convergence upper bound as the surrogate for this purpose, which is a common practiceÂ [14, 20, 38, 39, 44].

5.1 Analysis for the expected round time ğ”¼â€‹[T(r)â€‹(ğª)]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğª\mathbb{E}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})]

We summarize the insights of the obtained analytical round time in (25) as follows:

  • â€¢

    When we have unlimited or large enough bandwidth ftâ€‹oâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡f_{tot} (i.e., Kâ€‹ti/ftâ€‹oâ€‹tâ†’0â†’ğ¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡0{Kt_{i}}/{f_{tot}}\rightarrow 0), the approximated expected per-round time ğ”¼~â€‹[T(r)â€‹(ğ’’)]~ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ’’\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})] in (25) is determined by the computation heterogeneity Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i}, which is independent to sampling number Kğ¾K as clientsâ€™ computation performs in parallel.

  • â€¢

    In wireless networks, the communication is usually the bottleneck due to the limited bandwidth, e.g., the scale of communication time is larger than the scale of computation time. In particular, when Ï„iâ‰ªKâ€‹ti/ftâ€‹oâ€‹t,âˆ€iâˆˆğ’©formulae-sequencemuch-less-thansubscriptğœğ‘–ğ¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡for-allğ‘–ğ’©\tau_{i}\ll{Kt_{i}}/{f_{tot}},\forall i\in\mathcal{N}, the approximated expected round time ğ”¼~â€‹[T(r)â€‹(ğ’’)]~ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ’’\tilde{\mathbb{E}}\left[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right] is roughly linearly increasing with sampling number Kğ¾K, as a larger Kğ¾K reduces the communication bandwidth of each sampled client to upload the model parameters.

Remark: Although a smaller Kğ¾K leads to shorter expected round time, it does not mean a smaller Kğ¾K can reduce the total convergence time. This is because the total FL convergence time also depends on the number of training rounds for reaching the target precision. According to our obtained convergence result in TheoremÂ 1, a smaller Kğ¾K will leads to a slower convergence rate (e.g., a larger number of rounds Rğ‘…R for reaching the same error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon). Our experimental results in SectionÂ 6 also identify the impact of Kğ¾K on the performance of convergence time.

In the following, we solve Problem P3 as an approximation of the original Problem P1. Our empirical results in SectionÂ 6 demonstrate that the solution obtained from solving Problem P3 achieves the target precision with less time compared to baseline client sampling schemes.

5.3 Solving Problem P3

In this subsection, we first show how to obtain the unknown parameters, e.g., Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}, Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta. Then, we develop an efficient algorithm to solve Problem P3. We summarize the overall algorithm in AlgorithmÂ 2. Finally, we identify some insightful solution properties.

5.3.1 Estimation of Parameters Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i} and Î²Î±ğ›½ğ›¼\frac{\beta}{\alpha}

We first show how to estimate Î²Î±ğ›½ğ›¼\frac{\beta}{\alpha} via a substitute sampling scheme.111111We only need to estimate the value of Î²Î±ğ›½ğ›¼\frac{\beta}{\alpha} instead of Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta each, because we can divide parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha on the objective of Problem P3 without affecting the optimal sapling solution. Then, we show that we could indirectly acquire the knowledge of Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i} during the estimation process of Î²Î±ğ›½ğ›¼\frac{\beta}{\alpha}.

The basic idea is to utilize the derived convergence upper bound in (11) to approximately solve Î²Î±ğ›½ğ›¼\frac{\beta}{\alpha} as a variable, via performing AlgorithmÂ 1 with two baseline sampling schemes: uniform sampling ğªğŸsubscriptğª1\mathbf{q_{1}} with qi=1Nsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘{q}_{i}=\frac{1}{N} and weighted sampling ğªğŸsubscriptğª2\mathbf{q_{2}} with qi=pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–{q}_{i}=p_{i}, respectively.

Note that for sampling schemes ğªğŸsubscriptğª1\mathbf{q_{1}} and ğªğŸsubscriptğª2\mathbf{q_{2}}, we only run a limited number of rounds to reach a predefined loss Fssubscriptğ¹ğ‘ F_{s}. We donâ€™t run these schemes until they converge to the precision Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. This is because our goal is to find and run with the optimal sampling scheme ğªâˆ—superscriptğª\mathbf{q^{*}} so that we can achieve the target precision with the minimum wall-clock time.

Specifically, suppose RğªğŸ,ssubscriptğ‘…subscriptğª1ğ‘ R_{\mathbf{q_{1}},s} and RğªğŸ,ssubscriptğ‘…subscriptğª2ğ‘ R_{\mathbf{q_{2}},s} are the number of rounds for reaching the pre-defined loss Fssubscriptğ¹ğ‘ F_{s} for schemes ğªğŸsubscriptğª1\mathbf{q_{1}} and ğªğŸsubscriptğª2\mathbf{q_{2}}, respectively. According to (11), we have

{(Fsâˆ’Fâˆ—)â€‹RğªğŸ,sâ‰ˆÎ±â€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Npi2â€‹Gi2/K+Î²,(Fsâˆ’Fâˆ—)â€‹RğªğŸ,sâ‰ˆÎ±â€‹âˆ‘i=1Npiâ€‹Gi2/K+Î².casessubscriptğ¹ğ‘ superscriptğ¹subscriptğ‘…subscriptğª1ğ‘ ğ›¼ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘–2ğ¾ğ›½otherwisesubscriptğ¹ğ‘ superscriptğ¹subscriptğ‘…subscriptğª2ğ‘ ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘–2ğ¾ğ›½otherwise\begin{cases}\left(F_{s}-F^{*}\right)R_{\mathbf{q_{1}},s}\approx\alpha N{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}/K+\beta,\\ \left(F_{s}-F^{*}\right)R_{\mathbf{q_{2}},s}\approx\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}{p_{i}G_{i}^{2}}}/K+\beta.\end{cases} (34)

Based on (34), we have

RğªğŸ,sRğªğŸ,sâ‰ˆÎ±â€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Npi2â€‹Gi2/K+Î²Î±â€‹âˆ‘i=1Npiâ€‹Gi2/K+Î².subscriptğ‘…subscriptğª1ğ‘ subscriptğ‘…subscriptğª2ğ‘ ğ›¼ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘–2ğ¾ğ›½ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘–2ğ¾ğ›½\frac{R_{\mathbf{q_{1}},s}}{R_{\mathbf{q_{2}},s}}\approx\frac{\alpha N{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}/K+\beta}{\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}{p_{i}G_{i}^{2}}}/K+\beta}. (35)

We can calculate Î±Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\frac{\alpha}{\beta} from (35) once we know the value of Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}.

Notably, we can estimate Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i} during the procedure of estimating Î±Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\frac{\alpha}{\beta}. The idea is to let the sampled clients send back the norm of their local SGD along with their returned local model updates, and then the server updates Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i} with the received norm values. This approach does not add much communication overhead, since we only need to additionally transmit the value of the gradient norm (e.g., only a few bits for quantization) instead of the full gradient information.

In practice, due to the sampling variance, we may set several different Fssubscriptğ¹ğ‘ F_{s} to obtain an averaged estimation of Î±Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\frac{\alpha}{\beta}. The overall estimation process corresponds to LinesÂ 2â€“2 of AlgorithmÂ 2.

Problem P3 is non-convex.

5.3.3 Property of qâˆ—superscriptğ‘\boldsymbol{q}^{*}

Next we show some interesting properties of the optimal sampling strategy.

Theorem 3.

Consider the optimal solution of Problem P3 ğªâˆ—superscriptğª\boldsymbol{q}^{*}. For any two different clients iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j with Kâ€‹tiftâ€‹oâ€‹t+Ï„iâ‰¤Kâ€‹tjftâ€‹oâ€‹t+Ï„jğ¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–ğ¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘—\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\leq\frac{Kt_{j}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{j} and piâ€‹Giâ‰¥pjâ€‹Gjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğºğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğºğ‘—p_{i}G_{i}\geq p_{j}G_{j}, we have qiâˆ—â‰¥qjâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—q_{i}^{*}\geq q_{j}^{*}.

Proof.

We prove this theorem by contradiction. 6 Experimental Evaluation

In this section, we empirically evaluate the performance of our proposed client sampling scheme. We first present the evaluation setup and then show the experimental results. Our experiment code is available at:
https://github.com/WENLIXIAO-CS/WirelessFL

6.1 Experimental Setup

6.1.1 Platforms

We conduct experiments both on a networked hardware prototype system and in a simulated environment.131313The prototype implementation allows us to capture real system operation time, and the simulation system allows us to simulate large-scale FL environments with manipulative parameters. As illustrated in Fig. 2, our prototype system consists of N=40ğ‘40N=40 Raspberry Pis serving as clients and a laptop computer acting as the central server. All devices are interconnected via an enterprise-grade Wi-Fi router. We develop a TCP-based socket interface for the communication between the server and clients with bandwidth control. In the simulation system, we simulate N=100ğ‘100N=100 virtual devices and a virtual central server.

6.1.2 Datasets and Models

We evaluate our results on two real datasets and a synthetic dataset. For the real dataset, we adopt the widely used MNIST dataset and EMNIST dataset [10]. For the synthetic dataset, we follow a similar setup to that in [23], which generates 606060-dimensional random vectors as input data. We adopt both the convex multinomial logistic regression model and the non-convex convolutional neural network (CNN) model with LeNet-5 architecture [51].

6.1.3 Training Parameters

For all experiments, we initialize our model with ğ°0=ğŸsubscriptğ°00\mathbf{w}_{0}\!=\!\mathbf{0} and use a SGD batch size b=24ğ‘24b=24. We use an initial learning rate Î·0=0.1subscriptğœ‚00.1\eta_{0}=0.1 with a decay rate Î·01+rsubscriptğœ‚01ğ‘Ÿ\frac{{\eta}_{0}}{1+r}, where rğ‘Ÿr is the communication round index. We adopt the similar FedAvg settings as in [8, 16, 32, 23], where we sample 101010% of all clients in each round, i.e., K=4ğ¾4K\!=\!4 for Prototype Setup and K=10ğ¾10K\!=\!10 for Simulation Setups, with each client performing E=50ğ¸50E=50 local iterations.141414We also conduct experiments both on Prototype and Simulation Setups with variant Eğ¸E and Kğ¾K, which show a similar performance as the experiments in this paper.

6.1.4 Heterogeneous System Parameters

For the Prototype Setup, the computation time for E=50ğ¸50E=50 local iterations is almost the same amongst 40 devices, which we measured as Ï„iâ‰ˆ0.5subscriptğœğ‘–0.5\tau_{i}\approx 0.5 second. To enable a more heterogeneous communication time, we control clientsâ€™ bandwidth and generate a uniform distribution ti/ftâ€‹oâ€‹tâˆ¼ğ’°â€‹(0.22,5.04)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ’°0.225.04t_{i}/f_{tot}\sim\mathcal{U}(0.22,5.04) second, with a mean of 2.632.632.63 second and the standard deviation of 1.391.391.39 second. For the simulation system, we generate clientsâ€™ computation and communication time based on an exponential distribution, i.e., Ï„iâˆ¼expâ¡(1)similar-tosubscriptğœğ‘–1\tau_{i}\sim\exp{(1)} second and ti/ftâ€‹oâ€‹tâˆ¼expâ¡(1)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡1t_{i}/f_{tot}\sim\exp{(1)} second with both mean and standard deviation as 111 second.

6.2 Experimental Results

In this section, we first compare the performance of our proposed client sampling scheme (Algorithm 2) with different sampling baselines. Then, we evaluate the impact of the key system parameter on the total convergence time. We evaluate the wall-clock time performances of both the global training loss and test accuracy on the aggregated model in each round for all sampling schemes. We average each experiment over 202020 independent runs. For a fair comparison, we use the same random seed to compare sampling schemes in a single run and vary random seeds across different runs.

6.2.1 Comparison with Different Sampling Schemes

We compare the performance of our proposed client sampling scheme with three benchmarks 1) uniform sampling, 2) weighted sampling, and 3) statistical sampling where we sample clients according to statistical heterogeneity without system heterogeneity. Benchmarks 1â€“2 are widely adopted for convergence guarantees in [23, 21, 22, 24, 25]. The third baseline is an offline variant of the proposed schemes in [32, 33].161616The client sampling in [32, 33] is weighted by the norm of the local stochastic gradient in each round, which frequently requires the knowledge of stochastic gradient from all clients to calculate the sampling probabilities. Fig.Â 3, Fig.Â 4, and Fig.Â 5 show the results of Setup 1, Setup 2, and Setup 3, respectively. We summarize the key observations as follows.

  • â€¢

    Loss with Wall-clock Time: As predicted by our theory, Fig.Â 3(a), Fig.Â 4(a), and Fig.Â 5(a) show that our proposed sampling scheme achieves the same target loss with significantly less time, compared to the rest of baseline sampling schemes. Specifically, for Prototype Setup 111 in Fig.Â 3(a), our proposed sampling scheme spends around 717171% less time than uniform sampling, 393939% less time than statistical sampling, and 303030% less time than weighted sampling for reaching the same target loss. Fig.Â 5(a) highlights the fact that our proposed sampling works well with the non-convex CNN model, under which the naive uniform sampling cannot reach the target loss within 4,00040004,000 seconds, indicating the importance of a careful client sampling design. TableÂ 333 summarizes the superior performances of our proposed sampling scheme in wall-clock time for reaching target loss in all three setups.

  • â€¢

    Accuracy with Wall-clock Time: As shown in Fig.Â 3(b), Fig.Â 4(b), and Fig.Â 5(b), our proposed sampling scheme achieves the target test accuracy much faster than the other benchmarks. Notably, for Setup 222 with the target test accuracy 787878% in Fig.Â 4(b), our proposed sampling scheme takes around 444444% less time than uniform sampling, 626262% less time than statistical sampling, and 606060% less time than weighted sampling. We can also observe the superior test accuracy performance of our proposed sampling schemes in Prototype Setup 111 and non-convex Setup 333 in Fig.Â 3(b) and Fig.Â 5(b), respectively.

  • â€¢

    Loss with Number of Rounds: Fig.Â 3(c), Fig.Â 4(c), and Fig.Â 5(c) show that our proposed sampling scheme requires more training rounds for reaching the target loss compared to some of other baselines. This observation is expected since our proposed sampling scheme aims to minimize the wall-clock time instead of the number of rounds.

6.2.2 Impact of Client Sampling Number Kğ¾K

Fig.Â 666 shows the impact of the client sampling number Kğ¾K for our proposed optimal sampling scheme for SetupÂ 222. We see from Fig.Â 6(a) and Fig.Â 6(b) that as Kğ¾K increases, the time for our proposed optimal sampling scheme reaching the target loss and accuracy first decreases and then increases. In particular, the shortest time for reaching the target loss with is 617.1617.1617.1s under K=4ğ¾4K=4, compared to 4778.14778.14778.1s, 1272.51272.51272.5s, and 2021.62021.62021.6s under K=1ğ¾1K=1,101010, and 161616, respectively. This demonstrates the trade-off design for the number of Kğ¾K in wireless networks, as a smaller Kğ¾K benefits the per-round time (shown as in TheoremÂ 222) but requires more rounds for convergence (shown as in TheoremÂ 111), whereas a larger Kğ¾K benefits the number of rounds for convergence but yields a longer per-round time due to limited wireless bandwidth.

7 Conclusion and Future Work

In this work, we studied the optimal client sampling strategy that addresses the system and statistical heterogeneity in FL to minimize the wall-clock convergence time in wireless networks. For system heterogeneity, we proposed an adaptive bandwidth allocation scheme for the sampled clients in each round with arbitrary sampling probabilities to address the straggling effect. For statistical heterogeneity, we obtained a new tractable convergence bound for FL algorithms with arbitrary client sampling probabilities. Based on the bound, we formulated an analytically non-convex wall-clock time minimization problem. We developed an efficient algorithm to learn the unknown parameters in the convergence bound and designed a low-complexity algorithm to approximately solve the non-convex problem. Our solution characterizes the interplay between clientsâ€™ communication delays (system heterogeneity) and data importance (statistical heterogeneity) on the optimal client sampling design. We also identify a trade-off design for the number of sampled clients in each round, which balances the impact of wireless bandwidth limitation and convergence rate. Experimental results validated the superiority of our proposed scheme compared to several baselines in speeding up wall-clock convergence time.

Our client sampling optimization marks an initial effort to tackle system and statistical heterogeneity in FL. Looking ahead, we plan to transform our offline sampling strategy into an online one. This adaptation caters to practical wireless scenarios with changing channel conditions. Furthermore, weâ€™re considering a joint optimization of client sampling with other control variables, like the number of sampling instances or local iterations. This joint approach could further cut down total learning time.
